citation.article-title: Edwardsiella hoshinae, a new species of Enterobacteriaceae.

p.s: Description of Edwardsiella hoshinae sp. nov.

Edwardsiella hoshinae (Latin genitive (masculine) from Hoshina, in honor of the Japanese bacteriologist Toshikazu Hoshina, who was among the first persons to work with what we now call Edwardsiella spp.
All 27 Edwardsiella strains are Gram-negative, motile, peritrichous, nonsporeforming straight rods.
They grow on nutrient agar (30 and 37°C) giving flat or slightly convex colonies about 1-2 mm in diameter.
They are facultatively aerobic.
All 27 strains produced indole from peptone water, produced lysine and ornithine decarboxylase, reduced nitrates into nitrites, and were susceptible to the vibriostatic compound O/129.
Acid was produced (in peptone water, 1 day) from glucose, D-mannose, fructose, and D-galactose.
None of the 27 Edwardsiella strains could grow on M70 minimal agar glucose (without growth factor), Simmons' citrate, or KCN medium.
ONPG and Voges-Proskauer tests were negative.
Oxidase, urease, tryptophan deaminase, arginine decarboxylase, DNase, chitinase, lipase (tributyrin agar), Tween-80 esterase, and gelatinase were not produced.

Acid was not produced from adonitol, D-cellobiose, dulcitol, myo-inositol, lactose, D-melibiose, α-methyl-glucoside, mucate, polygalacturonate, D-raffinose, L-rhamnose, D-sorbitol, L-sorbose, and D-xylose.
Esculin was not hydrolyzed.
Results of DNA-relatedness studies obtained with labeled reference DNA from E. hoshinae 2-78 and from E. tarda 10396 are shown in Table 3.
The S1-resistant core [6] (in the incubated control tube containing labeled DNA only) was calculated as 7.3 ± 1% for E. hoshinae 2-78 and 6.9 ± 1.3% for E. tarda 10396 (results at both temperatures).

Typical and atypical E. tarda strains were, respectively, 81.5 ± 9.2% and 71.3 ± 2.0% related to strain 10396, and, respectively, 49.1 ± 6.3% and 49.0 ± 4.6% related to strain 2-78 at 60°C. E. hoshinae strains were 88.4 ± 10.8% and 43.6 ± 1.7% related, respectively, to strains 2-78 and 10396 at 60°C.
Results of hybridization experiments at 75°C were not dramatically different from those obtained at 60°C.
Percent divergence (∆Tm) was less than 0.7% between E. hoshinae strains and strain 2-78, and 9.7-10% between E. hoshinae strains and strain 10396.
Percent divergence was less than 3% between E. tarda strains (whether typical or atypical) and strain 10396, and 7.3 12.1% between E. tarda strains (typical and atypical) and strain 2-78.
All non-Edwardsiella strains tested were clearly distinct from both Edwardsiella strains 2-78 and 10396 on the basis of DNA relatedness (Table 4).

The base composition of the DNAs of E. tarda strains NCTC 10396 and CDC 3592-62 and E. hoshinae strains 2-78 and 490-72 were calculated to be, respectively (± standard deviation), 55.1 ± 0.3, 58.0 ± 0.7, 55.7 ± 0.1, and 57.1 ± 0.1 mol% G+C.
DNA of Escherichia coli K-12 was simultaneously found to have 51.2 ± 0.1 mol% G+C.
We designate strata 2-78 (CIP 78.56, ATCC 33379) as the type strain for E. hoshinae.

Although we had only 8 strains of E. hoshinae, we believe that publication of this new species will help other bacteriologists find E. hoshinae among unidentified mannitol-positive Edwardsiella-like strains.
The presently known habitat of E. hoshinae includes birds, reptiles, and water.
